results.title: The Gin game [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Terry Hughes, Nederlander Film and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A brilliantly acted comedy drama about a developing relationship between two very different individuals who reside in a nursing home - Weller (Hume Cronyn), a long time resident with a gruff and impatient exterior who has alienated most of the other elderly residents and timid newcomer, a diabetic, Fonsia (Jessica Tandy). Set on the sun porch of the nursing home, the two strike up a somewhat painful relationship over several games of gin rummy where each reminisces about their past, dredging up memories and emotions perhaps best left alone. Funny, sad, confronting, entertaining - it is a pleasure to watch two such great actors performing on stage. Originally produced for the Broadway stage and directed by Mike Nichols, D.L. Coburn’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play was a critical success travelling abroad to London and Russia and receiving the Tony and Drama Desk Awards for Jessica Tandy and the L.A. Drama Critics Circle Award for both Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn. This taped version for television was performed before a live audience in London in October 1979.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Mount Alexander
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Shire of Mount Alexander is located in the central region of Victoria. These nine stories cover the towns Castlemaine, Newstead and Maldon. Locals from the region discuss living in the country, the reasons for choosing to living in these towns and the community spirit so crucial to the region’s survival.

results.title: Theatre Royal: Castlemaine
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: A Castlemaine icon, the Theatre Royal is one of the oldest theatres in the country dating back to 1858. The owner in 2010, the projectionist, a burlesque performer and a local regular patron talk about their cinematic experiences, the history of the building, its architectural delights and how it is a major social centre for the town. Changing with the times, this is not only a single screen cinema, it offers music nights, community events, artist markets and even boasts a theatre ghost.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: The Empire of signs
results.creator_credit: Julia Cave, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American visions”.
This episode deals with some of the truths and illusions in America’s development as a huge-scale cultural consumer from 1950 through the end of the 1970s. It can be seen, in retrospect, how cultural patterns follow changes of attitude socially and politically. “Having the bomb confirmed the old belief in American exceptionalism,” says Hughes. The last half of the twentieth century was to be “The American Century” and, between 1945 and the late 1960s, New York succeeded Paris as the Western world’s art capital. The American styles that carried its reputation were Abstract Expressionism. The work of Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Barnett Newman and others, and its successor, Pop Art. The Pop Art movement was created by figures such as Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol. Hughes considers how Abstract Expressionism and Pop Art fit into a global America of nuclear anxiety and chromium opulence, and what happens to the avant-garde when the pursuit of the new becomes America’s official culture. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: American visions
results.brief_description: Written and presented by Robert Hughes, this 8 part series traces the development of America by following its art and architecture from Spanish settlement to the present day. results.title: The Gillies report
results.creator_credit: Ted Robinson, M I G Productions, Almost Managing Company and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Like a time capsule, this selection of highlights from the ABC television series “The Gillies report” captures some of the most memorable Australian political events, situations and politicians in a way you could never imagine. Features the brilliance and wit of Max Gillies along with some of Australia’s most highly talented writers and comedians including John Clarke, Wendy Harmer, Geoff Kelso, Richard Carleton, Tracy Harvey, Don Watson.

results.title: Age of anxiety
results.creator_credit: John Bush, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American visions”.
The subject of Hughes’ final program is American art of the late twentieth century. The United States entered the 1960’s as a rich and powerful nation, confident in its virtuous destiny, but by the end of the decade the dreams were shattered. The terrible conflict of Vietnam divided the country as it had not been divided since the Civil War a century earlier. America’s “Age of Anxiety” had begun. Hughes looks at the “tableaux” of Ed and Nancy Reddin Kienholz, works that range across the whole canon of American public imagery. He tells the story of the klutzy images of blood-stained Ku Klux Klansmen in the paintings of Philip Guston. He also meets many of the artists; Eric Fischl, Bruce Nauman and Louise Bourgeois, whose work reflects the uncertain society of the late sixties and early seventies. Hughes argues that it was Ronald Reagan’s economic policies that created the art-market boom of the 1980’s, with inflated prices and inflated egos. He confronts one of the darlings of the decade, former bond dealer Jeff Koons, in the hope of finding something meaningful in a large sculpture of a crucified kitten in a sock. For Hughes, the eighties were “a low, dishonest time for much American art.” Written and presented by Robert Hughes.
